title: Man Utd 'hire spying firms' to monitor potential transfer targets

Manchester United have reportedly taken the remarkable step of hiring "spying firms" to monitor potential signings.

According to The Athletic , the Red Devils have turned to secret operatives in order to carry out background checks before conducting any transfer business.

Led by executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward, the Old Trafford club are already preparing for a busy January having reportedly been given a shortlist of potential targets by manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

With a necessity to urgently strengthen their squad after their worst ever start to a Premier League season, the club are leaving no stone unturned in protecting their investment.

(Image: PA Wire/PA Images)

It is claimed the use of operatives has been introduced in order to become "more astute" after several failed big-money signings such as Alexis Sanchez and Angel di Maria.

The signing of Marcos Rojo from Sporting Lisbon in 2014 was also a motivating factor, after the club only discovered after shelling out £16million that he was facing an investigation over an alleged assault back in Argentina.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

United, who sit 12th in the Premier League table ahead of Sunday's visit of Liverpool , are said to be fearful of the January transfer window.

It has been claimed the club are worried about over inflated prices in what they consider a "difficult market" to do business, which favours selling clubs.

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

They have been linked to a host of strikers after struggling for goals, with Callum Wilson, Moussa Dembele and Mario Mandzukic heavily linked.

James Maddison, Declan Rice and Sean Longstaff are also said to be on Solskjaer's radar as he eyes young British players after the early success of summer signings Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Daniel James.

But it appears players will be the subject of stringent investigations to determine whether they are the right men for their Old Trafford overhaul.
description: Man Utd are reportedly leaving no stone unturned as they aim to make smart investments in the January transfer window
